children.value: and is not solvable in a finite number of steps by a formula. The implementation of both explicit and implicit multistep formulas is discussed in detail in
As with RK formulas, a multistep method is entirely specified by the values of a few constants.
present some of the most well-known and important formulas. The

(BD) are implicit. The tables also list the methods’ order of accuracy, to be defined shortly. We adopt the convention of referring to a multistep method by appending its order of accuracy to a two-letter name abbreviation, e.g., the AB3 method.

children.value: The definition of local truncation error is easily extended to multistep methods.
LTE and order of accuracy for a multistep
For the multistep formula defined by

children.label: MSLTE
children.html: τi+1(h)=u^(ti+1)−ak−1u^(ti)−⋯−a0u^(ti−k+1)h−[bkf(ti+1,u^(ti+1))+⋯+b0f(ti−k+1,u^(ti−k+1))]. \tau_{i+1}(h) = \frac{\hat{u}(t_{i+1}) - a_{k-1}\hat{u}(t_i) - \cdots - a_0 \hat{u}(t_{i-k+1})}{h} - \bigl[ b_kf(t_{i+1},\hat{u}(t_{i+1})) + \cdots + b_0f(t_{i-k+1},\hat{u}(t_{i-k+1})) \bigr].τi+1​(h)=hu^(ti+1​)−ak−1​u^(ti​)−⋯−a0​u^(ti−k+1​)​−[bk​f(ti+1​,u^(ti+1​))+⋯+b0​f(ti−k+1​,u^(ti−k+1​))].

children.value: To derive the LTE, we use the definition:

\begin{split}
    h\tau_{i+1}(h) &= \hat{u}(t_{i+1}) - \hat{u}(t_i) - hf\bigl(t_{i+1},\hat{u}(t_{i+1})\bigr) \\
    &= \hat{u}(t_i) + h\hat{u}'(t_i) + \frac{h^2}{2}\hat{u}''(t_i) + O(h^3)
    - \hat{u}(t_i) -h \hat{u}'(t_{i+1}) \\
    &= h\hat{u}'(t_i) + \frac{h^2}{2}\hat{u}''(t_i) + O(h^3)
    - h[\hat{u}'(t_i) + h\hat{u}''(t_i) + O(h^2)]\\
    &= - \frac{h^2}{2}\hat{u}''(t_i) + O(h^3).
\end{split}
children.html: hτi+1(h)=u^(ti+1)−u^(ti)−hf(ti+1,u^(ti+1))=u^(ti)+hu^′(ti)+h22u^′′(ti)+O(h3)−u^(ti)−hu^′(ti+1)=hu^′(ti)+h22u^′′(ti)+O(h3)−h[u^′(ti)+hu^′′(ti)+O(h2)]=−h22u^′′(ti)+O(h3).\begin{split} h\tau_{i+1}(h) &= \hat{u}(t_{i+1}) - \hat{u}(t_i) - hf\bigl(t_{i+1},\hat{u}(t_{i+1})\bigr) \\ &= \hat{u}(t_i) + h\hat{u}'(t_i) + \frac{h^2}{2}\hat{u}''(t_i) + O(h^3) - \hat{u}(t_i) -h \hat{u}'(t_{i+1}) \\ &= h\hat{u}'(t_i) + \frac{h^2}{2}\hat{u}''(t_i) + O(h^3) - h[\hat{u}'(t_i) + h\hat{u}''(t_i) + O(h^2)]\\ &= - \frac{h^2}{2}\hat{u}''(t_i) + O(h^3). \end{split}hτi+1​(h)​=u^(ti+1​)−u^(ti​)−hf(ti+1​,u^(ti+1​))=u^(ti​)+hu^′(ti​)+2h2​u^′′(ti​)+O(h3)−u^(ti​)−hu^′(ti+1​)=hu^′(ti​)+2h2​u^′′(ti​)+O(h3)−h[u^′(ti​)+hu^′′(ti​)+O(h2)]=−2h2​u^′′(ti​)+O(h3).​
τi+1(h)=O(h)\tau_{i+1}(h)=O(h)τi+1​(h)=O(h)

children.value: and AM1 (backward Euler) is a first-order method.
The AB2 method has the formula

children.html: ui+1=ui+h(32fi−12fi−1). {u}_{i+1} = u_i + h\left(\frac{3}{2} f_i - \frac{1}{2} f_{i-1} \right).ui+1​=ui​+h(23​fi​−21​fi−1​).
ρ(z)=z2−z\rho(z)=z^2-zρ(z)=z2−z
σ(z)=(3z−1)/2\sigma(z) = (3z-1)/2σ(z)=(3z−1)/2

children.value: . We find that the method is second order from the LTE:

\begin{split}
  h\tau_{i+1}(h)
  & = \hat{u}(t_{i+1}) - \hat{u}(t_i) - h\left[
    \frac{3}{2}f(t_i,\hat{u}(t_i)) - \frac{1}{2}f(t_{i-1},\hat{u}(t_{i-1}))
    \right]                                                                                   \\
  & = \hat{u}(t_i) + h\hat{u}'(t_i) + \frac{h^2}{2}\hat{u}''(t_i) + \frac{h^3}{6}\hat{u}'''(t_i) + O(h^4) \\
  & \qquad - \hat{u}(t_i) - \frac{3h}{2}\hat{u}'(t_i)  \\
  &\qquad  + \frac{h}{2} \bigl[\hat{u}'(t_i) - h\hat{u}''(t_i) + \frac{h^2}{2}\hat{u}'''(t_i) + O(h^3)\bigr]        \\
  & = \frac{5h^3}{12}\hat{u}'''(t_i) + O(h^4),
\end{split}
children.html: hτi+1(h)=u^(ti+1)−u^(ti)−h[32f(ti,u^(ti))−12f(ti−1,u^(ti−1))]=u^(ti)+hu^′(ti)+h22u^′′(ti)+h36u^′′′(ti)+O(h4)−u^(ti)−3h2u^′(ti)+h2[u^′(ti)−hu^′′(ti)+h22u^′′′(ti)+O(h3)]=5h312u^′′′(ti)+O(h4),\begin{split} h\tau_{i+1}(h) & = \hat{u}(t_{i+1}) - \hat{u}(t_i) - h\left[ \frac{3}{2}f(t_i,\hat{u}(t_i)) - \frac{1}{2}f(t_{i-1},\hat{u}(t_{i-1})) \right] \\ & = \hat{u}(t_i) + h\hat{u}'(t_i) + \frac{h^2}{2}\hat{u}''(t_i) + \frac{h^3}{6}\hat{u}'''(t_i) + O(h^4) \\ & \qquad - \hat{u}(t_i) - \frac{3h}{2}\hat{u}'(t_i) \\ &\qquad + \frac{h}{2} \bigl[\hat{u}'(t_i) - h\hat{u}''(t_i) + \frac{h^2}{2}\hat{u}'''(t_i) + O(h^3)\bigr] \\ & = \frac{5h^3}{12}\hat{u}'''(t_i) + O(h^4), \end{split}hτi+1​(h)​=u^(ti+1​)−u^(ti​)−h[23​f(ti​,u^(ti​))−21​f(ti−1​,u^(ti−1​))]=u^(ti​)+hu^′(ti​)+2h2​u^′′(ti​)+6h3​u^′′′(ti​)+O(h4)−u^(ti​)−23h​u^′(ti​)+2h​[u^′(ti​)−hu^′′(ti​)+2h2​u^′′′(ti​)+O(h3)]=125h3​u^′′′(ti​)+O(h4),​
τi+1(h)=O(h2)\tau_{i+1}(h)=O(h^2)τi+1​(h)=O(h2)

children.value: Although we will not present the analysis, the main conclusion for the multistep methods in this section is the same as for one-step methods.
The global error of each method in
converges at the same order as the local truncation error.
Where do coefficients like those in
come from? There are different ways to answer that question, but Adams and BD methods have distinctive stories to tell. The derivation of Adams methods begins with the observation that

children.label: adamsderive

children.value: . Like the trapezoid formula for a definite integral, AM2 computes the exact integral of a piecewise linear interpolant, and it often goes by the
In AB methods, the interpolating polynomial has degree

children.html: k−1k-1k−1

children.value: , which means that its interpolation error is

children.html: O(hk)O(h^k)O(hk)

children.value: . Upon integrating we get a local error of

children.html: O(hk+1)O(h^{k+1})O(hk+1)

children.value: , which reduces to a global error of

children.html: O(hk)O(h^k)O(hk)

children.value: . The AM interpolating polynomial is one degree larger, so its order of accuracy is one higher for the same number of steps.

children.value: If we must use an RK method to start anyway, why bother with multistep formulas at all? The answer is that multistep methods can be more efficient in some problems, even at the same order of accuracy.
